Title: A Randomised Controlled Trial Comparing Ventral and Dorsal Surgical Approaches for Cervical Spondylotic Myelopathy

Background: Cervical spondylotic myelopathy (CSM) is a leading cause of spinal cord dysfunction. This trial evaluates the effectiveness of ventral versus dorsal surgical approaches for CSM.

Methods: This multicenter randomised controlled trial recruited 250 patients with CSM from 11 sites over 18 months. Participants were randomised to ventral surgery or dorsal surgery (laminectomy/fusion or laminoplasty). The primary outcome was the Short Form-36 Physical Component Summary (PCS) score at one-year follow-up. Secondary outcomes included disease-specific measures, EuroQol-5D, and health resource utilization. Randomisation was computer-generated, with allocation concealment via sealed envelopes. Blinding was applied to outcome assessors.

Results: Of the 250 participants, 159 were randomised: 80 to ventral and 79 to dorsal surgery. Analysis was conducted on an intention-to-treat basis.
